Higher alcohols synthesis (HAS) from CO hydrogenation has attracted a considerable attention owing to their utilization in fuels and chemical intermediates. However, it is still very difficult to improve the selectivity of higher alcohols via the Fischer-Tropsch process. Based on the understanding of the current research progress, in the present work, a series of the Ce doped activated carbon loaded Co catalysts were prepared and characterized by XRD, XPS, N2 adsorption-desorption, H2-TPR, and CO2-TPD-MS etc. It was found that there is a linearly positive correlation between the selectivity of total alcohols and oxygen vacancies, so the improvement of the selectivity to total alcohols can be achieved by increasing the number of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface. The Co-7.5Ce/AC catalyst showed the maximum oxygen vacancy ratio (46.5%), exhibiting the best total alcohols selectivity (23.5%). This work revealed the roles of oxygen vacancies in the synthesis of higher alcohols from syngas and provided a new idea for the development of Co-based catalysts for the process. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Higher alcohols synthesis CO hydrogenation CeO2 Oxygen vacancy Co-based catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In order to meet the growing demand for energy resources and environmental protection and to reduce dependence on petroleum resources, catalytic conversion of syngas which can be obtained from coal, natural gas and biomass to higher alcohols is a more economical and promising route [1,2]. Higher alcohols have attracted a wide range of interest as power fuel substitutes and chemical feedstocks, and current efforts have focused on the development of efficient catalysts [3]. The catalysts used in the synthesis of high alcohols (HAS) from syngas can be classified into four types [4], mainly including Rh-based catalysts [5–7], Mo-based catalysts [8], modified methanol catalysts [9–11] and modified Fischer-Tropsch catalysts [12,13]. Among them, modified Fischer-Tropsch catalyst is one of the most promising catalysts due to low cost, favorable C2+ alcohols selectivity and excellent stability [14,15]. The direct production of higher alcohols from syngas involves the breaking and retention of CO bonds, and the generally accepted mechanism is the CO insertion mechanism [4], as shown in Fig. 1 . This process requires two active sites. Generally, the metal with zero valence (M0) is the active site for CO dissociation adsorption [16]; Metal cations (Mδ+) or the oxygen covered the surface of metals with zero valence [17] is the CO non-dissociative adsorption active site [12], and both teamwork to generate higher alcohols. By constructing dual or multi-metal active sites, the production of higher alcohols is promoted. Li et al. [18] prepared highly dispersed CoCu bimetallic catalysts, and they found that the Co was the CO dissociation active site, the Cu was the CO non-dissociative adsorption active site, and the CoCu active sites with intimate interaction were beneficial for HAS. Das et al. [19] reported a series of Cu-Co@MCN catalysts for ethanol synthesis from bio-derived syngas. They found that mesoporous nitrogen-rich carbon could stabilize the smaller size of Co crystals and promoted the effect of electron transfer. The presence of surface nitrogen stabilized CHO*, CH2O* species and achieved higher ethanol yields. Pei et al. [17] studied the high alcohols synthesis at cobalt metal/carbide interface and a significant selectivity for higher alcohols synthesis was observed. Density functional theory calculation revealed that Co2C was effective for non-dissociative adsorption of CO, the CoC2 and Co-metal constituted a double active site which promoted the formation of higher alcohols. Zhao et al. [20] also proposed that the synergistic effect between the metallic Co and Co2C phase was responsible for the formation of alcohols, and Mn created C-rich and H-lean surface chemical environment, which facilitated the formation of olefins. Ao et al. [21] prepared trimetallic Co-Ni-Cu catalysts with almost two times the C2+OH yield of monometallic Co catalysts. They concluded that with the addition of Cu, a Co-Ni-Cu alloy was formed, which promoted the formation of Co2C; Co0 were the active sites for CO dissociation and carbon chain growth, Ni0 and Cu0 were for CO non-dissociative adsorption and CO insertion to form oxygenates, while the Co2C species provided additional CO insertion sites. CeO2 has attracted much attention due to its redox properties and strong metal-support interactions [22–24], and it has been investigated to introduce into catalysts for the higher alcohols synthesis because it can make metals keep in the state of cation through strong interaction of it with the metals. Liu et al. [25] found that Cu/CeO2 catalysts had more stable Cu0 and Cu+ species and thus had higher activity than Cu/ZnO catalysts. Gnanamani et al. [26,27] proposed that the Co-CeO2 interface promoted the formation of oxygenates. Chen et al. [28] believed that the strong metal-support interactions between Co and CeO2 inhibited the reduction of CoOx, and Co-CoOx pairs were the active sites for the synthesis of higher alcohols, but the selectivity to total alcohols remains to be improved. It has been found [28–30] that the ratios of Coδ+-Co0 in the Co-Ce catalyst system can be regulated through regulating the Co0 particle size and the interface structure of Co on the carrier CeO2. Coδ+ species exists at the interface between Co0 particles and CeO2, and the ratios of Coδ+/Co0 is related to the Co0 particle size, and with the increase of Co0 particle size, the ratios of Coδ+/Co0 rise first and then drop. Shen et al. [31] also found that in Cu-CeO2 system, the interaction between Cu and CeO2 interface promoted the reduction of CuO and CeO2, and formed bilayer copper clusters, in which the upper layer is Cu0 and the lower layer is Cu+. Activated carbon (AC) has large specific surface area, rich pores and surface functional groups, suitable for use as adsorbent and catalyst carrier. In this work, a series of AC supporting Co-Ce catalysts were prepared by impregnation method, and it is expected that to improve simultaneously the selectivity to C2+OH and total alcohols by using the rich pores and surface functional groups on AC and the regulative role of CeO2 on the ratios of Coδ+/Co0. The catalyst performances were examined for the synthesis of higher alcohols from syngas. The relation between the catalyst structure and effect was discussed, and Ce roles were sketched by comparison with monometallic Co catalysts. It is found that there is a line correlation between oxygen vacancies on the surface of CeO2 and total alcohol selectivity, while no obvious dependence on the ratios of Coδ+/Co0. The present work points out that there are multiple active centers of CO non-dissociative adsorption and insertion in Co based catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation The activated carbon (AC) was derived from coconut shells. Activated carbon was washed several times with deionized water to remove impurities, then crushed 40–60 mesh. The cobalt-based catalysts with activated carbon as the carrier were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method. The specific steps were as follows: The activated carbon was added to deionized water and stirred at 100 °C for 20 min, filtered and washed several times. The process was repeated several times and then dried at 80 °C for 12 h. Aqueous solutions of Co(NO3)2 and Ce(NO3)3 were mixed and then placed to the treated activated carbon to impregnate for 12 h, followed by drying at 100 °C for 12 h and calcining at 350 °C for 5 h under nitrogen atmosphere. The content of cobalt was fixed at 15 wt% and cerium at x wt% (x = 0, 3, 5, 7.5, 10), and the obtained catalysts were named as Co-xCe/AC catalyst. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The N2 adsorption desorption tests of the catalysts were performed on a QDS-30 adsorber (Quantachrome, USA), and the amount of catalyst sample is 160 mg. The sample was degassed under vacuum at 200 °C for 4 h, and then the N2 adsorption and desorption tests were carried out at −196 °C. The surface areas were calculated by the BET(Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) formula, and the average pore volume and pore size were calculated by the BJH (Barret-Joyner-Halenda) method. The H2-TPR test was performed on a TP-5000 adsorption instrument (Tianjin Xianquan Instruments Co., Ltd.). The catalyst was loaded with 50 mg. The sample firstly heated to 150 °C under He atmosphere, keeping for 30 min, and cooled down to 50 °C. After that, the sample was switched to a mixture of 5% H2 and 95% N2 and ramped up to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min, and the TPR profile was recorded by a thermal conductivity detector. X-ray diffraction (XRD) characterization was completed on a RigakuD/MAX-2500 (Rigaku, Japan) X-ray diffractometer with a Cu target Kα as the radiation source. A target voltage of 40 kV and a target current of 100 mA were adopted, and the sample was scanned continuously at a speed of 8 °/min in the range of 10°−80° CO2-TPD-MS tests were performed on a TP-5080 adsorber (Tianjin Xianquan Instruments Co., Ltd.). The catalyst (100 mg) was heated to 400 °C in He atmosphere, and then reduced by a mixture of 5%H2 and 95%N2 for 30 min, After cooling down to 50 °C in He flow, the catalyst was purged for 30 min, and later, the sample was switched to CO2 to adsorb until saturation, then purged with He for 30 min to remove the physically adsorbed CO2 in the reaction tube and on the sample surface, and finally raised the temperature up to 650 °C at a rate of 10 °/min. The variations of the desorbed CO2 amount were detected by using a QIC-20 mass spectrometer. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer using Al Kα rays (hv=1486.6 eV) at an operating voltage of 12 kV and filament current of 6 mA. C1s=284.60 eV binding energy was used as the energy reference for charge correction. In-situ DRIFTS tests were performed on a Bruker INVENIO S IR spectrometer using a DTGS detector with 64 scans and a resolution of 4 cm−1. The catalyst was placed in an in-situ cell under Ar atmosphere (flow rate: 30 ml/min) at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min to 250 °C, keeping for 30 min at 250 °C. The background spectrum was subsequently scanned, then the synthesis gas (H2/CO=2:1) was introduced at a total flow rate of 30 ml/min while the spectra over time was scanned and recorded. After deducting the background spectrum, the time-dependent in-situ DRIFTS were obtained. 2.3 Catalyst test The catalyst activity evaluation was carried out on a fixed bed reactor. 0.3 g of catalyst mixed with 1.7 g of quartz sand was used for the reaction. Before the reaction, a 30% H2/N2 mixture was introduced at a flow rate of 90 ml/min and reduced at 400 °C for 4 h under atmospheric pressure. The reactor was cooled down to 250 °C in N2 atmosphere and then pressurized to 3.0 MPa., after that, the reactor was switched to synthesis gas (V(H2): V(CO) = 2:1, total flow rate of 75 ml/min). The products were analyzed using two sets of gas chromatograph. The CO, CH4 and CO2 were detected online by thermal conductivity measurements using a GC-950(TDX-01 filled column). Hydrocarbons, methanol and ethanol in the gas products were detected by flame ionization measurements using a HP-PLOT/Q capillary column. The liquid products were off-line analyzed by another GC-950. The alcohols in the liquid products were detected by flame ionization measurements using a HP-INNOWAX capillary column. The hydrocarbons in the liquid phase were detected by flame ionization measurements using a DB-5MSUI capillary column. The selectivity was calculated on carbon basis. The CO conversion (XCO ) and selectivity (Si ) were calculated by the following equations. X C O = ∑ n i ( g ) + ∑ n i ( l ) n ( C O ) i n × 100 % S i = n i ( g ) + n ( l ) ∑ n i ( g ) + ∑ n ( l ) × 100 % where n(CO) in is the mole number of CO in the syngas feed; i is the CO2, hydrocarbons and alcohols; ni (g) is the mole number of i component in the gas phase; ni (l) is the mole number of i component in the liquid phase. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 N2 adsorption-desorption analysis The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves of fresh Co-xCe/AC catalysts were shown in Fig. 2 . The adsorption and desorption isotherm of the catalysts belonged to the fourth type of isotherm, H4-type hysteresis loop, indicating that the catalysts contained a large number of micropores and mesopores. As shown in Fig. 2b, in addition to micropores, the mesopores of activated carbon were mainly distributed at 3.8 nm. The textural properties of AC supported catalysts were listed in Table 1 . The BET surface aera (SBET ), pore volume (Vp ) and average pore diameter (Dp ) of AC were 743.4 m2/g, 0.45 cm3/g and 2.42 nm, respectively. The SBET and Vp decreased to 590.2 m2/g and 0.34 cm3/g when Co was impregnated into the AC. With the introduction of different proportions of Ce, the SBET and Vp continuously decreased, which can be explained by anchoring of Co and Ce inside the pores of AC. Similar results has been reported by the literature [32]. 3.2 H2-TPR analysis As shown in Fig. 3 , the reducibility of Co-xCe/AC catalysts was tested by H2-TPR experiments. Three major hydrogen reduction peaks were observed in all catalysts, and the H2-TPR profiles of the Ce doped catalysts were nearly consistent with that of Co/AC catalyst, indicating that the reduction performance of Co-xCe/AC catalysts were similar to that of Co/AC catalyst. The first peak around 206–234 °C was ascribed to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO, and the subsequent reduction peak at 307–342 °C was attributed to the reduction of CoO to Co [33]. The hydrogen consumption peak about 450 °C could be assigned to methanation of the organic groups of the activated carbon support [34]. The former two reduction peaks of the catalysts loading CeO2 moved to higher reduction temperature, which had also been reported by Du [35] using Fe auxiliary. The more the CeO2 content increased, the higher the reduction peaks of low temperature shifted, which is consistent with the effect reported by the majority. With the addition of Ce, the position of the hydrogen consumption peak at 450 °C was slightly shifted to low temperature at Co-3Ce/AC and Co-5Ce/AC catalysts and then return to around 450 °C. That the reduction peaks of low temperature shifted to higher temperature indicated that the incorporation of CeO2 suppressed the reduction of Co species, showing the existence of a strong interaction between Co species and CeO2 and this interaction was enhanced with the increase of Ce content. 3.3 XRD analysis The XRD patterns of reduced catalysts were shown in Fig. 4 a. The characteristic diffraction peaks of reduced catalysts located at 2θ=44.2° could be assigned to metallic Co (111) (JCPDS card No. 89–7093). The diffraction peak about 28.6° was ascribed to CeO2 (111) (JCPDS card No. 89–8436). Fig. 4b shown XRD pattern of the Co-xCe/AC catalysts after reaction. The characteristic peaks with 2θ at 37.0°, 41.2°, 42.5°, 45.8°, 56.6° were attributed to (110), (002), (111), (021) and (112) of Co2C (JCPDS card No. 72–1369), and the diffraction peak at 2θ=44.2° was characteristic peak of metallic Co (111). Compared with the reduced catalysts, the Co species in the catalysts after reaction was mainly Co2C, which suggested that the main form of Co species existence changed during the CO hydrogenation [36]. 3.4 XPS analysis XPS analysis was performed to investigate the chemical state of the surface elements on spent catalysts. The XPS profiles of C 1 s were shown in Fig. 5 a, which evidenced three main bands including CC at 284.6 eV, CO at 285.7 eV, and C = O at 288.9 eV. Additionally, a weak peak with the binding energy (BE) at 283.5 eV was attributed to the formation of Co2C on the surface of catalyst [37]. The Co 2p profiles of the spent catalysts were shown in Fig. 5b. The Co 2p3/2 main peak located at the BE of 780.9 eV, with a satellite peak located at 786.2 eV, which indicates Co species with two valence states existed on the catalyst surface (see Fig. 5b): the peak with the BE of 778.4 eV was associated to Co0 and the peak with the BE of 781.2 eV, confirmed the formation of Co2C species on the surface of catalysts after reaction [38]. The result was consistent with the results of XRD analysis and the C 1 s spectra. The Ce 3d XPS spectra of all the spent catalysts were shown in Fig. 5c, which presented two kinds of spin-orbit lines [39,40], representing 3d5/2 and 3d3/2, labeled as ‘v’ and ‘u’. The characteristic peaks of Ce4+ exhibited three Ce 3d5/2 spin-obit at 882.5 eV(v’), 887.9 eV(v’’) and 898.8 eV(v’’’) and three main Ce 3d3/2 spin-obit at 901.1 eV(u’), 907.6 eV(u’’) and 916.7 eV(u’’’). The two-residual spin-orbit lines marked as v0(885.9 eV) and u0(904.4 eV) corresponding to Ce3+ 3d5/2 and Ce3+ 3d3/2, respectively. The formation of Ce3+ was associated with oxygen vacancies in the catalysts [41]. The O 1 s spectra was shown in Fig. 5d. The peaks at 529.9 eV and 533.2 eV were attributed to lattice oxygen(Oα) and surface hydroxy groups(Oγ) [42]. In addition, a wide shoulder peak at 531.6 eV was belonged to oxygen atoms(Oβ) near to the surface oxygen vacancies in the catalyst [39]. 3.5 CO2-TPD-MS analysis Fig. 6 displayed CO2-TPD-MS profiles of calcined Co-xCe/AC catalysts with different proportion of CeO2. The TPD profiles exhibited three temperature ranges of 50–230 °C, 230–450 °C and 450–650 °C arose from the weak, medium and strong basic sites, respectively. The weak basic sites derived from the surface hydroxyl group of catalysts and the moderate basic sites were originated from the acid-base electron pairs between metal and O2−. The strong basic sites were responsible for low-coordinated O2− ions on the catalyst surface [43,44]. The number of basic sites was shown in Table 2 . The percentage of moderate basic sites on the catalyst surface gradually increased from 32.6% to 48.1%. For Co-xCe/AC catalysts, the moderate basic sites originated from Co2+-O2− and Ce3+-O2− acid-base pairs, and Ce3+ was associated with oxygen vacancies. As shown in Table 2. With the introduction of Ce, the oxygen vacancies gradually enhanced percentage of moderate basic sites on the catalyst surface. Santos et al. [45] also reported that the basic sites stabilize oxygenated compounds, favoring the production of alcohols and inhibiting the production of hydrocarbons. 3.6 Catalytic performance The catalytic performance of Co-xCe/AC catalysts was shown in Table 3 . They were evaluated in a fixed bed reactor under the reaction conditions of 250 °C, 3.0 MPa, GHSV=15,000 ml/(gcat·h), and H2/CO molar ratio of 2. Hydrocarbons and alcohols were main products, and carbon dioxide proportion was very low, lower than 5%. The CO conversion of Co/AC catalyst reached 35.5%, and after the incorporation of Ce, the CO conversion decreased in different degrees. When Ce addition amount reached to 7.5 wt%, the CO conversion decreased to 16.0% on the Co-7.5Ce/AC catalyst. This implied that the introduction of Ce seemed to be detrimental to the conversion of CO. In terms of selectivity to hydrocarbons over the Co-xCe/AC catalysts, SCmHn was the maximum value of 86.4% over Co/AC catalyst, and the introduction of Ce clearly inhibited the production of hydrocarbons, especially the long-chain hydrocarbons, whose selectivity dropped from 22.4% to 5.3%. The CO2 selectivity of all catalysts maintained at a low level because the Co catalyst was not sensitive to water gas shift reaction. The selectivity of total alcohols was 9.8% over the Co/AC catalyst, with the C2+OH/ROH ratio of 70.7 wt%. After addition of CeO2, the SROH rose rapidly from 9.8% for Co/AC catalyst to 20.4% for Co-3Ce/AC catalyst, then increased slowly with Ce content and reached the maximum over the Co-7.5Ce/AC catalyst, which was 23.5%, while the C2+OH/ROH ratio had hardly changed, maintained about 70 wt% for all catalysts. These results indicated that the introduction of Ce suppressed the formation of hydrocarbons and facilitated the production of alcohols, but not improved obviously for the formation of C2+ alcohols. Fig. 7 shown the stability test of 200 h for Co-7.5Ce/AC catalyst. From Fig. 7 it is clear that the catalyst had outstanding stability, exhibited a promising trend. 3.7 The relation between the catalyst structure and catalytic effect The above catalytic performance evaluation results showed that the selectivity of Co/AC catalyst to total alcohols was greatly enhanced by Ce doping, N2 adsorption-desorption analysis indicated that CeO2 entered the inside of pore channel of activated carbon, and H2-TPR tests revealed that CeO2 inhibited the reduction of cobalt species. Combined with XRD and XPS characterization, Co2C was formed during CO hydrogenation reaction. The significant role of Co2C in the higher alcohols synthesis had been reported by Li [33], Cui [46] et al. and Fan [47] on Co-based catalysts, and the studies on Co-based catalysts promoted by additives such as La [48],Ca [34] and Ga [49] also suggested that Co2C was a CO non-dissociative adsorption site and the Co-Co2C double active sites produced C2+ alcohols, similar to the catalytic mechanism over Co-Cu and Fe-Cu bimetallic catalysts. Similarly, we found in this work that Co2C proportion in Co species of the catalysts after reaction did not change on the whole with the introduction of Ce and the increase of its content, which can be responded to C2+OH proportion in the total alcohols, in which no obvious change occurred for all catalysts (see Tables 4 and 3). This supports that Co2C was the active sites for CO non-dissociative adsorption and insertion. Further, we found that there was a linearly positive correlation between oxygen vacancies and total alcohol selectivity, as shown in Fig. 8 . In order to explore the deep reasons, in-situ DRIFTS (in-situ diffused reflectance infrared fourier transform spectroscopy) experiment were performed, and the results are shown in Fig. 9 and Table 5 . From the Fig. 9 and Table 5, it can be found that CHxO (2915 cm−1, 2848 cm−1), CH2 (1468 cm−1, 1456 cm−1), M=CH2 (1510 cm−1) and carbonate (1549 cm−1) species appeared both in Co/AC catalyst and Co-7.5Ce/AC catalysts, while OH (3400–3700 cm−1) and HCOO (1583 cm−1, 1347 cm−1) species only obviously appeared in Co-7.5Ce/AC, a catalyst containing Ce. This confirmed that there is a competitive another reaction route on the catalysts containing Ce. That is the H2O from CO hydrogenation dissociated at the oxygen vacancies to form OH* species, and subsequently, the OH* species participate in CO activation to generate HCOO* and then hydrogenated to form CHxO* species, which reacted with CHx* on the Co surface to form CHxCHxO*, after hydrogenation, produced CH3CH2OH, then the oxygen vacancies were vacated and continued to participate in the next step the dissociation of the involved water, thus forming a cycle. The CHx species on the Co surface were directly hydrogenated to produce methanol. In another route, Co2C is responsible for CO non-dissociative adsorption and insertion, and Co0 is for CO to produce surface carbon species CHx*. The dissociative adsorption CO reacted with the CHx* to form acetyl species CHxCO*, and then hydrogenated to produce ethanol. In short, the present study suggested the two reaction routes of Co0/Co2C and Co0/oxygen vacancy coexist on Co based catalysts, and the Co0/oxygen vacancy route becomes important as the number of oxygen vacancies increases. Fig. 10 4 Conclusion In this work, Co-xCe/AC catalysts were prepared by impregnation method and the catalytic performance was investigated. The results show that Ce has an important impact on the catalyst behaviors, and it make CO conversion decrease and total alcohols selectivity increase, from 9.8% for the Co/AC catalyst to 23.5% for the Co-7.5Ce/AC catalyst. This work revealed the two reaction routes coexist on Co based catalysts. One is Co0/Co2C double active site, where Co2C is responsible for CO non-dissociative adsorption and insertion, and Co0 is for CO to produce surface carbon species CHx*. The non-dissociative adsorption CO reacted with the CHx* to form oxygenate species with carbon chain growth, and finally produced C2+ alcohols. Another is Co0/oxygen vacancy double active site, where oxygen vacancy is for CO non-dissociative adsorption and insertion, in which the formation of OH*, HCOO* and CHxO* etc. intermediates was involved. The oxygen vacancies and total alcohol selectivity was linearly positively correlated, which made the oxygen vacancy route become important as the number of oxygen vacancies increases. The work provides a new idea for the development of Co-based catalysts for the synthesis of higher alcohols from syngas. coredata.dc:description: Higher alcohols synthesis (HAS) from CO hydrogenation has attracted a considerable attention owing to their utilization in fuels and chemical intermediates. However, it is still very difficult to improve the selectivity of higher alcohols via the Fischer-Tropsch process. Based on the understanding of the current research progress, in the present work, a series of the Ce doped activated carbon loaded Co catalysts were prepared and characterized by XRD, XPS, N2 adsorption-desorption, H2-TPR, and CO2-TPD-MS etc. It was found that there is a linearly positive correlation between the selectivity of total alcohols and oxygen vacancies, so the improvement of the selectivity to total alcohols can be achieved by increasing the number of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface. The Co-7.5Ce/AC catalyst showed the maximum oxygen vacancy ratio (46.5%), exhibiting the best total alcohols selectivity (23.5%). This work revealed the roles of oxygen vacancies in the synthesis of higher alcohols from syngas and provided a new idea for the development of Co-based catalysts for the process.
coredata.dc:title: Cerium doped Co/AC catalysts for higher alcohols synthesis from syngas
